Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Systematics of a pantropical diversification: the suboscine passerine birds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's finches of the Gal√°pagos Islands stand as one of the most impressive examples of evolution. After colonizing the islands, a single ancestral finch species eventually diversified into 13 species of different sizes, bill shapes, and ecologies. The suboscine passerine birds exhibit a similar history, but their diversification was not limited to a small set of islands; instead they are found throughout South America, Central America, North America, and parts of the Old World. There are now 1,300 species that differ dramatically in body shape and size, feeding behavior, and nest architecture. The primary goal of this project is to use DNA sequences to reconstruct the evolutionary history of these species, and to use this model system to investigate why the tropics are so biologically diverse.

A vital component of this collaborative project between U.S. and Brazilian scientists is the research training it will provide. With fieldwork planned in Argentina, Chile, Costa Rica, Malaysia, Venezuela, and Viet Nam, young scientists from a diversity of countries will be exposed not only to a diversity of natural environments but will also interact and forge relationships with their international peers. By working together to reconstruct perhaps the most spectacular evolutionary radiations of birds in the world, the researchers will learn how evolution works on a continental scale while training a new generation of scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcome of this project is a well-sampled evolutionary history of a massive tropical radiation - the 1,306 species of suboscine passerine birds. One in three Neotropical bird species is a suboscine, making this the perfect group to examine the origins of tropical biodiversity. The tropics are a natural laboratory for speciation research, with many high-profile studies over the years seeking answers to fundamental questions concerning species formation and maintenance.  Even the best of these studies sampled only a minority of the existing species within the clade in question and almost all used highly incomplete data matrices and supertree analyses, leaving results open to large estimation errors in all downstream analyses. Our sampling includes 1,962 vouchered specimens representing all genera and all but 19 of the 1,306 suboscine species. From each individual we collected DNA sequences from 2,389 orthologous regions across the genome.

We leveraged this unparalleled sampling of tropical diversity to illustrate the tempo and geography of evolution in the tropics. This was the first study to demonstrate conclusively that tropical biodiversity hotspots are linked to climates that are both moderate and stable, qualities which nurture diversity, lower extinction, and promote the gradual accumulation of species, but that, paradoxically, the hotspots are seeded by species born outside the hotspot in areas characterized by more extreme and less climatically stable climates.

Although most organismal diversity originates in the tropics, the remoteness of tropical regions and limited taxonomic knowledge of tropical groups have limited understanding of how tropical diversity forms. Our study was the first to be able to address tropical diversification with a large, comprehensively sampled clade and will pave the way for future investigations of evolution in the world’s diversity hotspots.
